message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination findings suggest non-accidental trauma, or child abuse. The presence of posterior rib fractures and bilateral retinal hemorrhages are highly specific for child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency may result in bleeding but not the fracture and hemorrhages seen in this case. Osteogenesis imperfecta may cause bone fractures but not necessarily rib fractures, and retinal hemorrhages are not commonly seen. Bacterial meningitis may cause lethargy and fever, but not the specific physical examination findings seen in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms - decreasing activity and excessive sleepiness, head injury with fever and neck pain, full anterior fontanelle, posterior rib fractures, and bilateral retinal hemorrhages - strongly suggests child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding but not rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages. Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause fractures but not retinal hemorrhages or head injury after a small fall. Bacterial meningitis can cause fever and lethargy, but not rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a head injury, decreased activity and excessive sleepiness, full anterior fontanelle, posterior rib fractures, and bilateral retinal hemorrhages suggests non-accidental trauma or child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding but not rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages. Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause fractures but not retinal hemorrhages or bruising. Bacterial meningitis does not explain the rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms present are indicative of child abuse, specifically shaken baby syndrome. The posterior rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages are key findings that suggest intentional injury. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding but not rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a rare genetic disease that causes brittle bones, but it would not result in retinal hemorrhages. Bacterial meningitis would cause fever and neck pain, but not rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages is highly concerning for child abuse, which can present with vague symptoms such as sleepiness and decreased activity. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding and bruising but it is unusual to cause fractured ribs. Osteogenesis imperfecta can lead to frequent fractures but it is rare for it to present with rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages. Bacterial meningitis usually presents with fever, neck stiffness and seizures, and there is no mention of these symptoms in the question stem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation of excessive sleepiness, decreasing activity, head injury, and posterior rib fractures with bilateral retinal hemorrhages is consistent with child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency and osteogenesis imperfecta do not cause these symptoms. Bacterial meningitis may cause lethargy and fever, but not rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages. An appropriate next step would be to involve child protection services and report suspected abuse.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms, including difficulty arousing, fontanelle fullness, rib fractures, and retinal hemorrhages, strongly suggests non-accidental trauma, also known as child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding, but is unlikely to cause rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages. Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause multiple bone fractures, but typically without the other symptoms present in this case. Bacterial meningitis can cause irritability and lethargy, but is not likely to cause rib fractures or retinal hemorrhages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a large, full anterior fontanelle, posterior rib fractures, and retinal hemorrhages are highly suspicious for child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding problems, but the rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages suggest physical trauma. Osteogenesis imperfecta is a rare genetic disorder that can cause fractures with minimal trauma, but retinal hemorrhages are not typical. Bacterial meningitis can cause symptoms of lethargy and fever, but the presence of rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages make child abuse a more likely cause.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of a history of head trauma, decreased activity and excessive sleepiness, full anterior fontanelle, and radiographic findings of posterior rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages are highly suggestive of child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency can cause bleeding, but it is unlikely to cause rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages. Osteogenesis imperfecta can cause bone fragility, but it is unlikely to cause retinal hemorrhages. Bacterial meningitis can cause decreased activity and excessive sleepiness, but it is unlikely to cause rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and physical examination suggest that the most likely cause is child abuse. Vitamin K deficiency typically presents with bleeding symptoms, Osteogenesis imperfecta presents with bone fractures that occur easily without trauma, and bacterial meningitis typically presents with fever, neck stiffness, and altered mental status. The presence of rib fractures and retinal hemorrhages are highly indicative of child abuse.
